title: What are the causes of chronic urticaria?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
What are the causes of chronic urticaria?

The causes of chronic urticaria can be diverse and may include autoimmune factors, infections, medications, and physical triggers. Chronic urticaria is defined by the occurrence of transient itchy wheals (hives) and/or angioedema for more than 6 weeks. It is divided into chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) and chronic inducible urticarias (CIndUs). CSU involves wheals and/or angioedema that occur suddenly and unpredictably without a specific trigger. The intake of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and infections such as Helicobacter pylori have been associated with chronic urticaria. Additionally, autoimmune factors and hormonal changes may also play a role in the development of chronic urticaria. If you have further questions or need more details about any specific cause, feel free to ask!

title: Does urticaria get worse during a pregnancy?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
Does urticaria get worse during a pregnancy?

The available information does not provide a clear answer to whether urticaria gets worse during pregnancy. However, it is known that hormonal changes during pregnancy can affect the immune system and may lead to changes in the severity of urticaria. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional if you are experiencing urticaria during pregnancy, as they can provide personalized advice and treatment options.

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
Can stress make urticaria worse?

Yes, stress can indeed make urticaria worse. Emotional stress can affect, reveal, or exacerbate a number of skin disorders, including urticaria, by releasing neuropeptides and modulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. It has been proposed that allergic inflammation and urticaria are characterized by mast cell degranulation and increased neuropeptide levels, which can be influenced by emotional stress.

If you are experiencing stress and notice that it is affecting your urticaria, it may be helpful to explore stress management techniques and seek support from a healthcare professional.

title: What role do infections play in chronic urticaria?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
What role do infections play in chronic urticaria?

In chronic urticaria, the role of infections is a topic of interest. Some studies have explored the potential association between infections and chronic urticaria, but the exact role of infections in causing or exacerbating chronic urticaria is not fully understood. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the specific impact of infections on your condition and to explore appropriate treatment options.

title: How do I get rid of my urticaria?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
How do I get rid of my urticaria?

The treatment of urticaria typically involves a standard approach with the goal of achieving complete freedom from symptoms. Patients are advised to avoid known triggers, including certain medications and relevant triggering stimuli. Symptomatic treatment is recommended for nearly all patients, and the first-line treatment usually involves second-generation H1-antihistamines.

It's important to consult a specialist to determine the most suitable treatment plan for your specific condition. Additionally, greater awareness of international guidelines and practice parameters is likely to improve the quality of care for patients with chronic urticaria.

If you have been experiencing urticaria, it is advisable to seek medical advice from a healthcare professional who can provide personalized treatment options based on your individual needs.

title: Which antihistamine is the best for urticaria?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
Which antihistamine is the best for urticaria?

The best antihistamines for urticaria are typically second-generation antihistamines, such as cetirizine (Zyrtec), loratadine (Claritin), fexofenadine (Allegra), and desloratadine (Clarinex). These antihistamines are preferred because they are less likely to cause drowsiness compared to first-generation antihistamines. However, the choice of antihistamine can vary depending on individual response and other factors, so it's important to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the best option for your specific case.

title: Can I increase the dose of omalizumab if the standard dose does not work?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
Can I increase the dose of omalizumab if the standard dose does not work?

According to the information I found, there are studies and reports that suggest an increase in the dose of omalizumab for better disease control in chronic spontaneous urticaria patients. However, it is important to consult with your healthcare provider before making any changes to your medication dosage. They can assess your specific situation and determine the best course of action for your treatment.

title: Which therapy works if omalizumab does not help?

conversation_history.content: Greetings! I am AIDUS, an AI assistant with access to a vast store of knowledge regarding urticaria. I can answer questions you might have about your condition, or you can pick one of the common questions from the sidebar to get started.
Which therapy works if omalizumab does not help?

If omalizumab does not provide relief for urticaria, the EAACI/GA2LEN/EDF/WAO urticaria guideline recommends considering cyclosporine as a fourth-line treatment option. This is especially recommended for patients with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) who do not respond to omalizumab within 6 months. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional to discuss the best course of action if omalizumab does not help with your urticaria symptoms.
